subject: TestCases per class vs. TestCases per fixture
msgSnippet: ... Dave made a very strong statement. I ve seen the quote from his book, but a few things I m missing. As one of the authors of JUnitDoclet I d like to add
messageBody:
Eric wrote:
> > I only recently became enamored of JUnit, as a result of
> > JUnitDoclet's creating a test framework for me. That shortened
> > the JUnit learning curve, which helped a lot.

Dave replied:
> As I said above (and will again, watch for a CoadLetter issue on the
> topic) there should be no explicit coorelation between classes being
> tested and TestCase subclasses.

Dave made a very strong statement. I've seen the quote from
his book, but a few things I'm missing. As one of the authors
of JUnitDoclet I'd like to add them here.

Before I continue, I'd like to confirm the additional need
for tests not directly related to one specific unit of the
code. (Even JUnitDoclet itself has TestCases like that.)

To organize tests like the application is one way to do it.
A natural one, indeed. From a strict testing perspective
the use of a TestCase for each class may not be the very
best way. (Reuse of fixture is an important point.)
But considering other perspectives I'm not convinced it
is as bad as Dave made it sound.

I like to have many tests. It was only natural to automate
the repeating part of test writing. So JUnitDoclet generates
Test skeletons and merges them with what was generated
(and modified) before.

In my experience, beginners to JUnit often find it difficult
to create the first TestCases. This is used as an excuse not
to test at all. (It's a lame excuse, I know.) Once they've
got started, they discover the power of unit testing.
Unfortunately they have to start first. ;-)

Please consider the result of JUnitDoclet as an managed
starting point. It is providing places to fill in tests
both to beginners and to experienced developers.

If someone want's more then the generated test code, he/she
can add TestCases or even TestSuites that contain TestCases
for different aspects (with different fixtures), ...

The very basic fixture may be the instance to test. In a
significant number of cases that could be just what is
needed.

One major thing I like about tests related to specific units
of code:
The tests are documenting the intention behind the code.

When I look at my code later, I like to go to the test and
see what the code was ment to do. The underestimated part
of that idea is, to keep the test structure in sync as the
application is refactured. Here is one major difference to
other tools I know: refactoring support. Only if the test
structure is _following_ the application structure we keep
the "documenting aspect of tests" up to date.

I see the benefits from the structure Dave described and
think about whether or not generating them somehow. But I'm
not sure about the survival of the "documenting aspect of
tests". Wouldn't separate "methods with long names" be
better from _that_ point of view? (We still can/should factor
out the creation and destruction of a reused fixture.)
What do you think?

Kind regards,

Steffen
